title: Counting and place value
subject: Kindergarten

title: Place value
subject: 1st grade
description: We will learn about the ones and tens place values and compare 2-digit numbers.

title: Addition and subtraction
subject: 1st grade
description: First  we will learn how addition and subtraction relate.  Next  we will add and subtract numbers less than or equal to 20 and solve addition and subtraction word problems.  Finally  we will begin adding 2-digit numbers.

title: Measurement data and geometry
subject: 1st grade
description: First  we will compare objects by length and measure objects with same-size length units without gaps or overlaps.  Next  we will read and interpret bar graphs  tell time on an analog clock  and learn about shapes.

title: Place value
subject: 2nd grade
description: We will learn about the ones  tens  and hundreds place values and compare 3-digit numbers.

title: Addition and subtraction within 100
subject: 2nd grade
description: Learn to add and subtract two-digit numbers within 100.

title: Addition and subtraction within 1000
subject: 2nd grade
description: Learn to add and subtract two- and three-digit numbers within 1000.

title: Measurement data and geometry
subject: 2nd grade
description: First  we will measure length using unit squares and rulers  compare and estimate length  and solve length word problems.  Next  we will read and make picture graphs  bar graphs  and line plots.  From there  we will tell time on analog clocks and count U.S. coins and dollars. After that  we will identify quadrilaterals  pentagons  hexagons  and octagons.  Finally  we will break shapes into equal parts.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
subject: 6th grade
description: Ratios  rates  and percentages are some of the most useful math concepts in real life (and what is REAL life anyway  huh?). From baking recipes to sports  these concepts wiggle their way into our lives on a daily basis.

title: Arithmetic operations
subject: 6th grade
description: The most fundamental branch of math is arithmetic operations. It consists of adding  subtracting  multiplying  and dividing numbers. We're willing to bet that doing these operations on whole numbers is a piece of cake  but now we'll mix those numbers up with decimals and fractions. We'll also introduce the idea exponents as they become much more important moving forward. So sharpen that pencil and relax in your chair  we're going for a ride!

title: Negative numbers
subject: 6th grade
description: Negative numbers are a necessary part of our understanding of mathematics and the world. The idea of anything "negative" is often seen as "bad." Negative numbers are not only good  but they're fun! Walk through this tutorial with us and we'll show you how they are defined  interpreted  and applied. Absolute value is a type of negative number that is expressed as a positive. Confused? Don't be. We got your back.

title: Properties of numbers
subject: 6th grade
description: Learn how to find the least common multiple (LCM) and greatest common factor (GCF).

title: Variables & expressions
subject: 6th grade
description: Learn what variables are and practice using them in expressions. The major concepts covered in these tutorials are substitution  the distributive property  and combining like terms.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
subject: 6th grade
description: Learn about equations and inequalities that have variables in them. These tutorials focus on solving equations and understanding solutions to inequalities.

title: Geometry
subject: 6th grade
description: Learn how to find the area  volume  and surface area of all sorts of geometric shapes. Also work with shapes on the coordinate plane.

title: Data and statistics
subject: 6th grade
description: In statistics  we try to make sense of the world by collecting  organizing  analyzing  and presenting large amounts of data. For example  you may survey your friends about what tv show is most popular  but the small sample size will not give you an accurate idea of what ALL 6th graders like to watch. To do this you must survey a cross section of students from all around the country and all backgrounds. The data can then be statistically analyzed to give a more accurate picture of what tv show is most popular. So let's dive into a discussion of statistics  including box and whisker plots  bar charts  pictographs  line graphs  and dot plots.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
subject: 7th grade
description: Add and subtract negative numbers  and see how absolute value can be used to find the distance between any two numbers on the number line.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
subject: 7th grade
description: Learn to multiply and divide negative numbers. Once you've got the basics down  we'll revisit fractions  exponents  and order of operations but this time with negatives!

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
subject: 7th grade
description: In these tutorials  we'll explore the number system. We'll convert fractions to decimals  operate on numbers in different forms  meet complex fractions  and identify types of numbers. We'll also solve interesting word problems involving percentages (discounts  taxes  and tip calculations).

title: Rates & proportional relationships
subject: 7th grade
description: Learn all about proportional relationships. How are they connected to ratios and rates? What do their graphs look like? What types of word problems can we solve with proportions?

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
subject: 7th grade
description: Bring on the algebra! Learn how to manipulate expressions and solve equations and inequalities.

title: Geometry
subject: 7th grade
description: Geometric shapes are all around us. The world is built with them. In this series of tutorials and exercises you'll become familiar with Euclidean geometry and terms like segments  scale drawings  parts of a circle  area  volume  angles  and geometric figures.

title: Statistics and probability
subject: 7th grade
description: This introduction to probability and statistics explores probability models  sample spaces  compound events  random samples  and a whole lot more.

title: Numbers and operations
subject: 8th grade
description: Math is all about numbers (like 89 and 3.14) and operations (like addition and multiplication). In these tutorials  we learn about a some new types of numbers and some new types of operations.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
subject: 8th grade
description: Learn how to solve more complicated  multi-step equations like 4x + 5 = 6x -7.

title: Linear equations and functions
subject: 8th grade
description: Linear equations like y = 2x + 7 are called "linear" because they make a straight line when we graph them. These tutorials introduce you to linear relationships  their graphs  and functions.

title: Systems of equations
subject: 8th grade
description: A "system of equations" is when we're dealing with more than one equation at the same time. These tutorials show you how to set up and solve systems of equations.

title: Geometry
subject: 8th grade
description: In this topic  we will learn about special angles  such as angles between intersecting lines and triangle angles.  Next  we will learn about the Pythagorean theorem.  We will find volume of 3D shapes like spheres  cones  and cylinders.  Finally  we will learn about translations  rotations  reflections  and congruence and similarity.

title: Geometric transformations
subject: 8th grade
description: In this topic you will learn how to perform the transformations  specifically translations  rotations  reflections  and dilations and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

title: Data and modeling
subject: 8th grade
description: In this topic  we will learn about scatter plots  lines of best fit  and two-way tables.

title: Addition and subtraction
subject: Arithmetic
description: In this topic  we will add and subtract whole numbers. The topic starts with 1+1=2 and goes through adding and subtracting within 1000.  We will cover regrouping  borrowing  and word problems.

title: Multiplication and division
subject: Arithmetic
description: In this topic  we will multiply and divide whole numbers. The topic starts with 1-digit multiplication and division and goes through multi-digit problems.  We will cover regrouping  remainders  and word problems.

title: Negative numbers
subject: Arithmetic
description: Learn about numbers below 0 and how they relate to positive numbers.  Add  subtract  multiply and divide negative numbers.

title: Fractions
subject: Arithmetic
description: In this topic  we will explore fractions conceptually and add  subtract  multiply  and divide fractions.

title: Decimals
subject: Arithmetic
description: In this topic  we will learn what a decimal is and how to show it visually and on a number line.  We will also add  subtract  multiply  and divide with decimals.

title: Lines
subject: Basic geometry
description: Learn what lines  line segments  and rays are and how to use them.

title: Angles
subject: Basic geometry
description: In this topic  we will learn what an angle is and how to label  measure and construct them.  We will also explore special types of angles.

title: Shapes
subject: Basic geometry
description: Classify shapes and solve problems using what we know of the properties of shapes.

title: Coordinate plane
subject: Basic geometry
description: We use coordinates to describe where something is. In geometry  coordinates say where points are on a grid we call the "coordinate plane".

title: Area and perimeter
subject: Basic geometry
description: Area and perimeter help us measure the size of 2D shapes. We’ll start with the area and perimeter of rectangles. From there  we’ll tackle trickier shapes  such as triangles and circles.

title: Volume and surface area
subject: Basic geometry
description: Volume and surface area help us measure the size of 3D objects. We’ll start with the volume and surface area of rectangular prisms. From there  we’ll tackle trickier objects  such as cones and spheres.

title: Pythagorean theorem
subject: Basic geometry
description: The Pythagorean theorem describes a special relationship between the sides of a right triangle. Even the ancients knew of this relationship. In this topic  we’ll figure out how to use the Pythagorean theorem and prove why it works.

title: Transformations congruence and similarity
subject: Basic geometry
description: Learn about geometric transformations and how they're used to understand the meaning of "similar" and "congruent".

title: Arithmetic properties
subject: Pre-algebra
description: This tutorial will help us make sure we can go deep on arithmetic. We'll explore various ways to represent whole numbers  place value  order of operations  rounding and various other properties of arithmetic.

title: Factors and multiples
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Understanding and finding factors and multiples. After these videos  you'll be ready for fractions.

title: Reading and interpreting data
subject: Pre-algebra
description: This topic is less about statistics and more about interpreting data--whether it is presented as a table  pictograph  bar graph or line graph.  Good for someone new to these ideas.  For a student in high school or college looking to learn statistics  it might make sense to skip (although it might not hurt either).

title: Measurement
subject: Pre-algebra
description: From length to area to volume to time  thinking about how we measure things.

title: Fractions
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Understanding fractions conceptually  using operations with fractions  and converting fractions.

title: Decimals
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Understanding decimals conceptually  using operations with decimals  rounding and estimating with decimals  and converting decimals.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Extending our understanding of numbers below 0.  Thinking about "absolute" distance from 0.  We will also look at all 4 quadrants on the coordinate plane.

title: Ratios rates proportions
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Learn all about proportional relationships. How are they connected to ratios and rates? What do their graphs look like? What types of word problems can we solve with proportions?

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
subject: Pre-algebra
description: In this topic  we will look at 1- and 2-step equations  as well as expressions and inequalities.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
subject: Pre-algebra
description: Understanding and solving exponents  radicals  and scientific notation without algebra.

title: Foundations
subject: Algebra basics
description: This topic isn't algebra  but it is a survey of all of the most important pre-algebra skills you need to really digest algebra.  These skills also tend to be pretty important in life in general!

title: Algebraic expressions
subject: Algebra basics
description: The core idea in algebra is using letters to represent relationships between numbers without specifying what those numbers are!

title: Linear equations and inequalities
subject: Algebra basics
description: We will now equate two algebraic expressions and think about how it might constrain what value the variables can take on.  The algebraic manipulation you learn here really is the heart of algebra.

title: Graphing lines and slope
subject: Algebra basics
description: Use the power of algebra to understand and interpret points and lines (something we typically do in geometry).  This will include slope and the equation of a line.

title: Systems of equations
subject: Algebra basics
description: Solving a system of equations or inequalities in two variables by elimination  substitution  and graphing.

title: Expressions with exponents
subject: Algebra basics
description: Let's build our toolkit that allow us to manipulate exponents algebraically.

title: Quadratics and polynomials
subject: Algebra basics
description: We'll now progress beyond the world of purely linear expressions and equations and enter the world of quadratics (and more generally polynomials).  Learn to factor expressions that have powers of 2 in them and solve quadratic equations.  We'll also learn to manipulate more general polynomial expressions.

title: Equations and geometry
subject: Algebra basics
description: See how algebra can be useful when solving geometrical problems.

title: Algebra foundations
subject: Algebra I
description: This unit is an overview of some fundamental ideas and tools we'll be using throughout algebra.

title: Solving equations & inequalities
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to solve linear equations and inequalities that contain a single variable. For example  we'll solve equations like 2(x+3)=(4x-1)/2+7 and inequalities like 5x-2≥2(x-1).

title: Working with units
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we start to think about some general modeling concerns before we dive into modeling situations with different kinds of functions and equations throughout the course.

title: Linear equations & graphs
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn about linear equations and how we can use their graphs to solve problems.

title: Forms of linear equations
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to write linear equations in different forms to reveal different features of their relationships.

title: Systems of equations
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to write systems of equations  solve those systems  and interpret what those solutions mean.

title: Inequalities (systems & graphs)
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we study inequalities like x+2y>5 and graph them. This helps us see their solutions. We also explore systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities at the same time) and use them to describe real-world situations.

title: Functions
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn about functions  which are mathematical entities that assign unique outputs to given inputs. We'll evaluate  graph  analyze  and create various types of functions.

title: Sequences
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn about the various ways in which we can define sequences. We'll construct arithmetic and geometric sequences to describe patterns and use those sequences to solve problems.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to solve and graph absolute value and piecewise equations.

title: Exponents & radicals
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we review exponent rules and learn about higher-order roots like the cube root (or 3rd root). We'll learn how to calculate these roots and simplify algebraic expressions with radicals.

title: Exponential growth & decay
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to construct  analyze  graph  and interpret basic exponential functions of the form f(x)=a⋅bˣ.

title: Quadratics Multiplying & factoring
subject: Algebra I
description: There are a lot of great ways to multiply and factor integers. In this unit  we'll build on those strategies to learn how to multiply and factor algebraic expressions.

title: Quadratic functions & equations
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn how to solve quadratic equations  and how to analyze and graph quadratic functions.

title: Irrational numbers
subject: Algebra I
description: In this unit  we learn about irrational numbers and how to identify them.

title: Geometry foundations
subject: High school geometry
description: Review your knowledge about angles  triangles  quadrilaterals  and area.

title: Transformations
subject: High school geometry
description: In this topic you will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations  specifically translations  rotations  reflections  and dilations.  You will learn how to perform the transformations  and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

title: Congruence
subject: High school geometry
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent  and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.

title: Similarity
subject: High school geometry
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be similar  and how to determine whether two figures are similar or not. Use this concept to prove geometric theorems and solve some problems with polygons.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
subject: High school geometry
description: Triangles are not always right (although they are never wrong)  but when they are it opens up an exciting world of possibilities.  Not only are right triangles cool in their own right (pun intended)  they are the basis of very important ideas in analytic geometry (the distance between two points in space) and trigonometry.

title: Solid geometry
subject: High school geometry
description: Extend your knowledge about two-dimensional shapes to three dimensions!

title: Analytic geometry
subject: High school geometry
description: In analytic geometry  also known as coordinate geometry  we think about geometric objects on the coordinate plane. For example  we can see that opposite sides of a parallelogram are parallel by writing a linear equation for each side and seeing that the slopes are the same.

title: Circles
subject: High school geometry
description: Explore  prove  and apply important properties of circles that have to do with things like arc length  radians  inscribed angles  and tangents.

title: Polynomial arithmetic
subject: Algebra II
description: In Algebra 2  students learn about the analog between polynomials and the integers  through adding  subtracting  and multiplying polynomials. This also paves the way for factoring and dividing polynomials.

title: Complex numbers
subject: Algebra II
description: Complex numbers are built on the idea that we can define the number i (called "the imaginary unit") to be the principal square root of -1  or a solution to the equation x²=-1. From this starting point evolves a rich and exciting world of the number system that encapsulates everything we have known before: integers  rational  and real numbers.

title: Polynomial factorization
subject: Algebra II
description: In Algebra 1  students rewrote (factored) quadratic expressions as the product of two linear factors. This helped them learn about the behavior of quadratic functions. In Algebra 2  we extend this idea to rewrite polynomials in degrees higher than 2 as products of linear factors. This will help us investigate polynomial functions. It also allows us to prove polynomial identities  which are mathematical statements that describe numerical relationships.

title: Polynomial division
subject: Algebra II
description: After we have added  subtracted  and multiplied polynomials  it's time to divide them! This will prove to be a little bit more sophisticated. It turns out that not every polynomial division results in a polynomial. When it doesn't  we end up with a remainder (just like with integer division!).

title: Polynomial graphs
subject: Algebra II
description: In this unit  we will use everything that we know about polynomials in order to analyze their graphical behavior. Specifically  we will find polynomials' zeros (i.e.  x-intercepts) and analyze how they behave as the x-values become infinitely positive or infinitely negative (i.e.  end-behavior).

title: Rational exponents and radicals
subject: Algebra II
description: In middle school  students learned about integer powers—first positive and then also negative. In Algebra 2  we extend this concept to include rational powers. We will define how they work  and use them to rewrite exponential expressions in various ways.

title: Exponential models
subject: Algebra II
description: In Algebra 1  students worked with simple exponential models to describe various real-world situations. In Algebra 2  we go deeper and study models that are more elaborate.

title: Logarithms
subject: Algebra II
description: Logarithms are the inverses of exponents. They allow us to solve hairy exponential equations  and they are a good excuse to dive deeper into the relationship between a function and its inverse.

title: Transformations of functions
subject: Algebra II
description: In Algebra 1  students reasoned about graphs of absolute value and quadratic functions by thinking of them as transformations of the parent functions |x| and x². In this unit  we extend this idea to include transformations of any function whatsoever. This fascinating concept allows us to graph many other types of functions  like square/cube root  exponential and logarithmic functions.

title: Equations
subject: Algebra II
description: In Algebra 1  students solves linear and quadratic equations  and learned how the two processes are based on the same logical principles. In this unit  we extend these processes to solve a greater variety of equations  like rational and radical equations. We learn that we may sometimes get extraneous solutions. We also solve systems that include quadratic equations  and learn how we can use graphs to estimate a solution for any kind of equation!

title: Trigonometry
subject: Algebra II
description: In Geometry  students learned about the trigonometric ratios sine  cosine  and tangent. In this unit  we extend these ideas into functions that are defined for all real numbers! We learn about the behavior of those functions and use them to model real-world situations.

title: Modeling
subject: Algebra II
description: This unit dives deeper into the world of modeling. We will take our knowledge about all the different function types we were exposed to so far  and use it to model and analyze various phenomena.

title: Rational functions
subject: Algebra II
description: Just as the polynomials are analogous to the integers  rational functions are analogous to the rational numbers. We will learn more about this analogy as we rewrite various rational expressions  and also think about their graphical behavior.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
subject: Trigonometry
description: Learn the basics of trigonometry: What are sine  cosine  and tangent? How can we use them to solve for unknown sides and angles in right triangles?

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
subject: Trigonometry
description: Learn how to use trigonometry in order to find missing sides and angles in any triangle.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
subject: Trigonometry
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
subject: Trigonometry
description: Learn how to graph trigonometric functions and how to interpret those graphs. Learn how to construct trigonometric functions from their graphs or other features.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
subject: Trigonometry
description: Learn how to solve trigonometric equations and how to use trigonometric identities to solve various problems.

title: Analyzing categorical data
subject: Statistics and probability
description: This unit covers methods for dealing with data that falls into categories. Learn how to use bar graphs  Venn diagrams  and two-way tables to see patterns and relationships in categorical data.

title: Displaying and comparing quantitative data
subject: Statistics and probability
description: This unit covers some basic methods for graphing distributions of quantitative data like dot plots  histograms  and stem and leaf plots. We'll also explore how to use those displays to compare the features of different distributions.

title: Summarizing quantitative data
subject: Statistics and probability
description: This unit covers common measures of center like mean and median. We'll also learn to measure spread or variability with standard deviation and interquartile range  and use these ideas to determine what data can be considered an outlier.

title: Modeling data distributions
subject: Statistics and probability
description: This unit takes our understanding of distributions to the next level. We'll measure the position of data within a distribution using percentiles and z-scores  we'll learn what happens when we transform data  we'll study how to model distributions with density curves  and we'll look at one of the most important families of distributions called Normal distributions.

title: Exploring bivariate numerical data
subject: Statistics and probability
description: We use scatter plots to explore the relationship between two quantitative variables  and we use regression to model the relationship and make predictions. This unit explores linear regression and how to assess the strength of linear models.

title: Study design
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Statistics is all about forming questions and gathering data to explore those questions. This unit covers sampling and survey methods  observational studies  and basic experiment design.

title: Probability
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Probability tells us how often some event will happen after many repeated trials. This topic covers theoretical  experimental  compound probability  permutations  combinations  and more!

title: Counting permutations and combinations
subject: Statistics and probability
description: This unit covers methods for counting how many possible outcomes there are in various situations. We'll learn about factorial  permutations  and combinations. We'll also look at how to use these ideas to find probabilities.

title: Random variables
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Random variables can be any outcomes from some chance process  like how many heads will occur in a series of 20 flips. We calculate probabilities of random variables and calculate expected value for different types of random variables.

title: Sampling distributions
subject: Statistics and probability
description: A sampling distribution shows every possible result a statistic can take in every possible sample from a population and how often each result happens. This topic covers how sample proportions and sample means behave in repeated samples.

title: Confidence intervals
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Confidence intervals give us a range of plausible values for some unknown value based on results from a sample. This topic covers confidence intervals for means and proportions.

title: Significance tests (hypothesis testing)
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Significance tests give us a formal process for using sample data to evaluate the likelihood of some claim about a population value. We calculate p-values to see how likely a sample result is to occur by random chance  and we use p-values to make conclusions about hypotheses.

title: Two-sample inference for the difference between groups
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Learn how to apply what you know about confidence intervals and significance tests to situations that involve comparing two samples to see if there is a significant difference between the two populations.

title: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Chi-square tests are a family of significance tests that give us ways to test hypotheses about distributions of categorical data. This topic covers goodness-of-fit tests to see if sample data fits a hypothesized distribution  and tests for independence between two categorical variables.

title: Advanced regression (inference and transforming)
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Advanced regression will introduce you to regression methods when data has  a nonlinear pattern.

title: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
subject: Statistics and probability
description: Analysis of variance  also called ANOVA  is a collection of methods for comparing multiple means across different groups.

title: Scatterplots
subject: High school statistics
description: Scatterplots show us relationships and patterns in data  and we use those patterns to make predictions.

title: Data distributions
subject: High school statistics
description: Data makes more sense when we graph it and summarize it with numbers.

title: Two-way tables
subject: High school statistics
description: Two-way tables show us relationships between categorical variables.

title: Study design
subject: High school statistics
description: Getting reliable data is vital if we want to make correct conclusions.The process of collecting data through studies involves sampling  observations  surveys  and experiments.

title: Probability
subject: High school statistics
description: Few things are certain in life. Probability gives us an idea of the likelihood or unlikelihood of different outcomes.

title: Binomial probability
subject: High school statistics
description: If you roll five dice  what’s the probability that three of them show a 6? In a group of 20 strangers  what’s the probability that more than half of them were born in the summer? Learn about binomial probability to answer these types of problems.

title: Normal distributions
subject: High school statistics
description: A Normal distribution is a very special and common distribution that is fundamental to learning about statistics. Normal distributions describe many real world phenomena from scores on exams to lengths of wings on bugs.

title: Analyzing categorical data
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: This unit covers methods for dealing with data that falls into categories. Learn how to use bar graphs  Venn diagrams  and two-way tables to see patterns and relationships in categorical data.

title: Displaying and describing quantitative data
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: This unit covers some basic methods for graphing distributions of quantitative data like dot plots  histograms  and stem and leaf plots. We'll also explore how to use those displays to compare the features of different distributions.

title: Summarizing quantitative data
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: This unit covers common measures of center like mean and median. We'll also learn to measure spread or variability with standard deviation and interquartile range  and use these ideas to determine what data can be considered an outlier.

title: Modeling data distributions
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: This unit takes our understanding of distributions to the next level. We'll measure the position of data within a distribution using percentiles and z-scores  we'll learn what happens when we transform data  we'll study how to model distributions with density curves  and we'll look at one of the most important families of distributions called Normal distributions.

title: Exploring bivariate numerical data
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: We use scatter plots to explore the relationship between two quantitative variables  and we use regression to model the relationship and make predictions. This unit explores linear regression and how to assess the strength of linear models.

title: Study design
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Statistics is all about forming questions and gathering data to explore those questions. This unit covers sampling and survey methods  observational studies  and basic experiment design.

title: Probability
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: This unit on probability covers how to use simulations to calculate experimental probabilities and a variety of other methods (the addition rule  the multiplication rule  conditional probability) for calculating probability. Later  we'll use our understanding of probability to answer statistical questions.

title: Random variables
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: A random variable is some outcome from a chance process  like how many heads will occur in a series of 20 flips (a discrete random variable)  or how many seconds it took someone to read this sentence (a continuous random variable). We calculate probabilities of random variables  calculate expected value  and look what happens when we transform and combine random variables.

title: Sampling distributions
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: A sampling distribution shows every possible result a statistic can take in every possible sample from a population and how often each result happens. This unit covers how sample proportions and sample means behave in repeated samples.

title: Confidence intervals
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Confidence intervals give us a range of plausible values for some unknown population parameter based on results from a sample. This unit covers confidence intervals for means and proportions using data from one sample.

title: Significance tests (hypothesis testing)
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: If a basketball player says they make 75% of the shots they take  but they only make 65% of shots in a sample  does that mean they're lying? Significance tests give us a formal process for using sample data to evaluate how plausible a claim about a population value is. We calculate P-values to see how likely sample results are to occur by random chance  and we use P-values to make conclusions about hypotheses.

title: Inference comparing two groups or populations
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: If a poll from one location shows 55% of voters support a measure  but a poll from another location shows 45% support  does that mean there is a difference between the two populations? We can make a confidence interval to estimate the difference  or do a significance test to see if the difference is significant. We'll use similar methods to compare the means of two groups.

title: Chi-square tests for categorical data
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Learn to test how well sample counts of a categorical variable fit some hypothesized distribution  or  if the distribution of a categorical variable is similar or not across multiple groups.

title: More on regression
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Learn how to perform inference on slope in least-squares regression. We'll make confidence intervals and do significance tests to see if a linear relationship in a sample suggests a relationship exists in the corresponding population.

title: Prepare for the 2020 AP®︎ Statistics Exam
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Check out some examples of worked free-response items from previous exams  and practice choosing an appropriate inference procedure given a scenario.

title: AP®︎ Statistics Standards mappings
subject: AP®︎ Statistics
description: Dig into the world of AP®︎ Statistics and find out how our free course material aligns with the standards set by the College Board.

title: Complex numbers
subject: Precalculus
description: In Algebra 2  students were introduced to the complex numbers and performed basic operations with them. In this unit  we extend this concept and perform more sophisticated operations  like dividing complex numbers. We also learn about a different way to represent complex numbers—polar form.

title: Polynomials
subject: Precalculus
description: In Algebra 2  students learned a lot about polynomial functions. In this unit  we tackle advanced topics like the Binomial Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra. We will also perform more challenging polynomial division and dive deeper into the graphical method for solving equations.

title: Composite functions
subject: Precalculus
description: We can compose functions by making the output of one function the input of another one. This simple-yet-rich idea opens up a world of fascinating applications.

title: Trigonometry
subject: Precalculus
description: In Algebra 2  students learned about the trigonometric functions. In this unit  we extend this world by proving various trigonometric identities and defining the inverse trigonometric functions  which allow us to solve trigonometric equations.

title: Vectors
subject: Precalculus
description: Learn what vectors are and how they can be used to model real-world situations. Perform various operations with vectors like adding  subtracting  scaling  and conversion between rectangular to polar coordinates.

title: Matrices
subject: Precalculus
description: Learn what matrices are and about their various uses: solving systems of equations  transforming shapes and vectors  and representing real-world situations. Learn how to add  subtract  and multiply matrices  and find the inverses of matrices.

title: Series
subject: Precalculus
description: An assortment of concepts in math that help us deal with sequences and proofs.

title: Conic sections
subject: Precalculus
description: Learn about the four conic sections and their equations: Circle  Ellipse  Parabola  and Hyperbola.

title: Probability and combinatorics
subject: Precalculus
description: Probability and combinatorics are the conceptual framework on which the world of statistics is built. Besides this important role  they are just fascinating and surprisingly fun!

title: Limits and continuity
subject: Differential Calculus
description: Limits describe the behavior of a function as we approach a certain input value  regardless of the function's actual value there. Continuity requires that the behavior of a function around a point matches the function's value at that point. These simple yet powerful ideas play a major role in all of calculus.

title: Derivatives definition and basic rules
subject: Differential Calculus
description: The derivative of a function describes the function's instantaneous rate of change at a certain point. Another common interpretation is that the derivative gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point. Learn how we define the derivative using limits. Learn about a bunch of very useful rules (like the power  product  and quotient rules) that help us find derivatives quickly.

title: Derivatives chain rule and other advanced topics
subject: Differential Calculus
description: The chain rule tells us how to find the derivative of a composite function. This is an exceptionally useful rule  as it opens up a whole world of functions (and equations!) we can now differentiate. Also learn how to use all the different derivative rules together in a thoughtful and strategic manner.

title: Applications of derivatives
subject: Differential Calculus
description: Derivatives describe the rate of change of quantities. This becomes very useful when solving various problems that are related to rates of change in applied  real-world  situations. Also learn how to apply derivatives to approximate function values and find limits using L’Hôpital’s rule.

title: Analyzing functions
subject: Differential Calculus
description: The first and the second derivative of a function can be used to obtain a lot of information about the behavior of that function. For example  the first derivative tells us where a function increases or decreases and where it has maximum or minimum points; the second derivative tells us where a function is concave up or down and where it has inflection points.

title: Parametric equations polar coordinates and vector-valued functions
subject: Differential Calculus
description: We are used to working with functions whose output is a single variable  and whose graph is defined with Cartesian  i.e.  (x y) coordinates. But there can be other functions! For example  vector-valued functions can have two variables or more as outputs! Polar functions are graphed using polar coordinates  i.e.  they take an angle as an input and output a radius! Learn about these functions and how we apply the concept of the derivative on them.

title: Integrals
subject: Integral Calculus
description: The definite integral of a function gives us the area under the curve of that function. Another common interpretation is that the integral of a rate function describes the accumulation of the quantity whose rate is given. We can approximate integrals using Riemann sums  and we define definite integrals using limits of Riemann sums. The fundamental theorem of calculus ties integrals and derivatives together and can be used to evaluate various definite integrals.

title: Differential equations
subject: Integral Calculus
description: Differential equations are equations that include both a function and its derivative (or higher-order derivatives). For example  y=y' is a differential equation. Learn how to find and represent solutions of basic differential equations.

title: Applications of integrals
subject: Integral Calculus
description: Definite integrals are all about the accumulation of quantities. Let's see how they are applied in order to solve various kinds of problems.

title: Parametric equations polar coordinates and vector-valued functions
subject: Integral Calculus
description: We are used to working with functions whose output is a single variable  and whose graph is defined with Cartesian  i.e.  (x y) coordinates. But there can be other functions! For example  vector-valued functions can have two variables or more as outputs! Polar functions are graphed using polar coordinates  i.e.  they take an angle as an input and output a radius! Learn about these functions and how we apply the concept of the integral on them.

title: Series
subject: Integral Calculus
description: Series are sums of multiple terms. Infinite series are sums of an infinite number of terms. Don't all infinite series grow to infinity? It turns out the answer is no. Some infinite series converge to a finite value. Learn how this is possible and how we can tell whether a series converges and to what value. We will also learn about Taylor and Maclaurin series  which are series that act as functions and converge to common functions like sin(x) or eˣ.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
subject: Multivariable calculus
description: The only thing separating multivariable calculus from ordinary calculus is this newfangled word "multivariable".  It means we will deal with functions whose inputs or outputs live in two or more dimensions.  Here we lay the foundations for thinking about and visualizing multivariable functions.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
subject: Multivariable calculus
description: What does it mean to take the derivative of a function whose input lives in multiple dimensions?  What about when its output is a vector?  Here we go over many different ways to  extend the idea of a derivative to higher dimensions  including partial derivatives​  directional derivatives  the gradient  vector derivatives  divergence  curl  etc.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
subject: Multivariable calculus
description: The tools of partial derivatives  the gradient  etc. can be used to optimize and approximate multivariable functions.  These are very useful in practice  and to a large extent this is why people study multivariable calculus.

title: Integrating multivariable functions
subject: Multivariable calculus
description: There are many ways to extend the idea of integration to multiple dimensions: Line integrals  double integrals  triple integrals  surface integrals  etc.  Each one lets you add infinitely many infinitely small values  where those values might come from points on a curve  points in an area  points on a surface  etc.    These are all very powerful tools  relevant to almost all real-world applications of calculus.  In particular  they are an invaluable tool in physics.

title: Green's Stokes' and the divergence theorems
subject: Multivariable calculus
description: Here we cover four different ways to extend the fundamental theorem of calculus to multiple dimensions.  Green's theorem and the 2D divergence theorem do this for two dimensions  then we crank it up to three dimensions with Stokes' theorem and the (3D) divergence theorem.

subject: Differential equations

title: Second order linear equations
subject: Differential equations

subject: Differential equations

title: Alternate coordinate systems (bases)
subject: Linear algebra
description: We explore creating and moving between various coordinate systems.

They represent ratios as expressions  and represent equivalent ratios with double number line diagrams  tape diagrams  and tables. They use these terms and representations in reasoning about situations involving color mixtures  recipes  unit pricing  and constant speed.
